title: National Mall and Memorial Parks
listingDescription: Officially established in 1965, National Mall and Memorial Parks contains some of the oldest protected park lands in the National Park Service. The sprawling lands include the Mall, the public promenade extending from 3rd Street near the Capitol to 14th Street. America's front lawn has hosted various historic events related to the civil rights movement, as well as memorializing some of the great moments in American history.

images.altText: the Vietnam Veterans Memorial and Washington Monument at sunset

bodyText:
Officially established in 1965, National Mall and Memorial Parks contains some of the oldest protected park lands in the National Park Service. The sprawling lands include the Mall, the public promenade extending from 3rd Street near the Capitol to 14th Street. The National Mall is the continuation of that space where congressionally authorized park icons, such as the Washington Monument, WWII and Lincoln Memorials stand. This historic expanse is the linear area between the Potomac River and Capital Reflecting Pool. In addition to the memorial core, the park includes some 156 reservations, circles, fountains and other open spaces, all of which serve as the nation’s front yard. Ford’s Theatre, The House where Lincoln died, Potomac Park, Hains Point and Pennsylvania Avenue NHS are also among the park managed areas that constitute National Mall and Memorial Parks.

Having over 1,000 acres of National Park Service managed land at the heart of our nation’s capital, National Mall and Memorial Parks provides visitors with abundant opportunities to get in touch with our heritage. With everything from colossal monuments to commemorative gardens, from presidential inaugurals to civil rights demonstrations, National Mall and Memorial Parks hosts history in the making. Numerous First Amendment activities and special events are held in the park each year to honor the courage, sacrifice and devotion to duty of war veterans; celebrate the United States commitment to freedom, equality and democratic ideals; and enjoy symbolic architecture, historic vistas and renowned natural landscapes.

title: Northeast Portico

images.altText: Gray stone wall with green tinted lettering
images.title: Northeast chamber Panel
images.caption: Northeast chamber panel of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial

bodyText:
The quotes below show, in their entirety, the correspondents and writings of Thomas Jefferson that appear as excerpts on the northeast chamber panel. 

"But let them [members of the parliament of Great Britain] not think to exclude us from going to other markets, to dispose of those commodities which they cannot use, nor41 to supply those wants which they cannot supply. Still less let it be proposed that our properties within our own territories shall be taxed or regulated by any power on earth but our own. The god who gave us life gave us liberty at the same time: the hand of force may destroy, but cannot disjoin them." - "A Summary View of the Rights of British America"

"For in a warm climate, no man will labour for himself who can make another labour for him. This is so true, that of the proprietors of slaves a very small proportion indeed are ever seen to labor. And can the liberties of a nation be thought secure when we have removed their only firm basis, a conviction in the minds of the people that these liberties are the gift of God? That they are not to be violated but with his wrath? Indeed I tremble for my country when I reflect that God is just: that his justice cannot sleep for ever . . . ." - Notes on the State of Virginia, Query XVIII

"The whole commerce between master and slave is a perpetual exercise of the most boisterous passions, the most unremitting despotism on the one part, and degrading submissions on the other. Our children see this, and learn to imitate it. . . ." - Notes on the State of Virginia, Query XVIII

"Nothing is more certainly written in the book of fate than that these people are to be free. Nor is it less certain that the two races, equally free, cannot live in the same government. Nature, habit, opinion has drawn indelible lines of distinction between them." - Jefferson's Autobiography

"Preach, my dear sir, a crusade against ignorance; establish & improve the law for educating the common people." - Jefferson to George Wythe, August 13, 1786 

"It is an axiom in my mind that our liberty can never be safe but in the hands of the people themselves, and that too of the people with a certain degree of instruction. This it is the business of the state to effect, and on a general plan." - Jefferson to George Washington, January 4, 1786

title: Northwest Portico

images.altText: Gray stone wall with green tinted lettering
images.title: Northwest Portico
images.caption: Northwest Portico

bodyText:
The northwest portico wall houses a snippet of the Thomas Jefferson's BIll for Establishing Religious Freedom. Below one can find the full text.

"Well aware that the opinions and belief of men depend not on their own will, but follow involuntarily the evidence proposed to their minds; that Almighty God hath created the mind free, and manifested his supreme will that free it shall remain by making it altogether insusceptible of restraint; that all attempts to influence it by temporal punishments, or burthens, or by civil incapacitations, tend only to beget habits of hypocrisy and meanness, and are a departure from the plan of the holy author of our religion...Be it enacted by the General Assembly that no man shall be compelled to frequent or support any religious worship, place, or ministry whatsoever, nor shall be enforced, restrained, molested, or burthened in his body or goods, nor shall otherwise suffer, on account of his religious opinions or belief; but that all men shall be free to profess, and by argument to maintain, their opinions in matters of religion, and that the same shall in no wise diminish, enlarge, or affect their civil capacities." - "A Bill for Establishing Religious Freedom", Section I

title: Southeast Portico

images.altText: Gray stone wall with green tinted lettering
images.title: Southeast Portico
images.caption: Southeast Portico of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial

bodyText:
"I am certainly not an advocate for frequent and untried changes in laws and constitutions. I think moderate imperfections had better be borne with; because, when once known, we accommodate ourselves to them, and find practical means of correcting their ill effects. But I know also, that laws and institutions must go hand in hand with the progress of the human mind. As that becomes more developed, more enlightened, as new discoveries are made, new truths disclosed, and manners and opinions change with the change of circumstances, institutions must advance also, and keep pace with the times. We might as well require a man to wear still the coat which fitted him when a boy, as civilized society to remain ever under the regimen of their barbarous ancestors." - Jefferson to H. Tompkinson (AKA Samuel Kercheval), July 12, 1816 

The Inscription an excerpt of a letter from Jefferson to Samuel Kercheval. This selection emphasis Thomas Jefferson’s belief in the need for government to continue to change and evolve for the benefit of society.

title: Southwest Portico – Declaration of Independence

images.altText: Gray stone wall with green tinted lettering
images.title: Southwest Chamber Panel
images.caption: Southwest Chamber Panel

bodyText: The Southwest panel highlights selections from the United States Declaration of Independence. The quote is written in chronological order as it was in the original document. This is different from the other quotes on the wall.

title: Statue of Thomas Jefferson and the Symbology on the statue

images.altText: Brown colored statue of a man
images.title: Thomas Jefferson Memorial Statue
images.caption: Thomas Jefferson Memorial Statue

bodyText:
New York sculptor artist Rudolph Evans was selected by the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission to undertake the portrait statue of Thomas Jefferson. The 19’ tall bronze statue was installed in April of 1947, replacing the original statue which due to wartime restrictions on the use of precious metals, was made of plaster-of-Paris. What is Jefferson looking at? The statue faces north towards the White House which he lived in as our Third President. Jefferson also looks toward the monument to his fellow Virginia revolutionary, George Washington. Some point out that Jefferson may be keeping a wary eye on Alexander Hamilton, his great political foe. Hamilton's statue, by James Earle Fraser, is on the south side of the U.S. Treasury Building.

If one were to walk behind the Thomas Jefferson statue, several things appear to confirm Jefferson's love of the land and agriculture. These interest are represented by a stack of books and stalks of corn.

title: The Corner Stone and Time Capsule

images.altText: Stone corner of a structure with letters carved into it.
images.title: Thomas Jefferson Memorial Cornerstone
images.caption: Thomas Jefferson Memorial Cornerstone

bodyText: On Dec. 15, 1938, President Franklin D. Roosevelt participated in the groundbreaking ceremony for the Thomas Jefferson Memorial. One year later, on Nov. 15, 1939, with the foundation work completed, President Roosevelt returned to place the memorial cornerstone & time capsule. FDR used the same Masonic trowel George Washington had used in laying the cornerstone of the U.S. Capitol Building.

title: The Memorials Around the Tidal Basin
listingDescription: The Jefferson, Roosevelt, and King memorials connect, both chronologically and thematically, clockwise around the Tidal Basin.

images.altText: A white building sits in the distance, surrounded by water and trees with red leaves
images.title: The Memorials Around the Tidal Basin
images.caption: The Thomas Jefferson Memorial surrounded by fall foliage on the Tidal Basin

bodyText:
The Jefferson, Roosevelt, and King memorials connect, both chronologically and thematically, clockwise around the Tidal Basin. 
 

Thomas Jefferson lived April 13, 1743 – July 4, 1826. 

The memorial was authorized by Congress on June 26, 1934.  

Official dedication date: April 13, 1943 
 

Franklin Delano Roosevelt lived January 30, 1882 – April 12, 1945. 

The memorial was authorized by Congress on August 11, 1955. 

Official dedication date: May 2, 1997 
 

Martin Luther King, Jr. Lived January 15, 1929 – April 4, 1968. 

The memorial was authorized by Congress on November 12, 1996. 

Official dedication date: August 28, 2011 

The Declaration of Independence, adopted on July 4, 1776, set forth ideals for this country. Many of Roosevelt’s New Deal programs provided economic opportunity for those that needed help. King’s work in the Civil Rights Movement to attain fairer social and economic opportunity sought to make the ideals contained in the Declaration of Independence a reality for all Americans. The beginning and end goal are one.

title: The Tympanum (triangular area above the entrance of the memorial)
bodyText: In the Tympanum is a bas-relief sculpture by Adolf Weinman depicting the Committee of Five tasked on June 11, 1776, with writing a Declaration of Independence. The members of the committee included Thomas Jefferson of Virginia, Roger Sherman of Connecticut, Benjamin Franklin of Pennsylvania, Robert R. Livingston of New York, and John Adams of Massachusetts.

title: Thomas Jefferson Memorial
listingDescription: Thomas Jefferson (1743-1826) was the third president of the United States, Secretary of State in George Washington's cabinet, and the author of the Declaration of Independence. Begun as a New Deal construction project, the Thomas Jefferson Memorial was completed in 1943. The imposing marble structure's columns and Monticello-esque dome bear selections of Jefferson's writings on several themes including religion, education, freedom, and government. Additional exhibits and rest

images.altText: Domed memorial with columns on waterfront.
images.title: Thomas Jefferson Memorial at Dusk
images.caption: The Thomas Jefferson Memorial at dusk.

bodyText:
Thomas Jefferson (1743-1826) was the third president of the United States, Secretary of State in George Washington's cabinet, and the author of the Declaration of Independence. Begun as a New Deal construction project, the Thomas Jefferson Memorial was completed in 1943. The imposing marble structure's columns and Monticello-esque dome bear selections of Jefferson's writings on several themes including religion, education, freedom, and government. Additional exhibits and restrooms are located on the lower level.

Inscriptions

Beneath rotunda
I HAVE SWORN UPON THE ALTAR OF GOD ETERNAL HOSTILITY AGAINST EVERY FORM OF TYRANNY OVER THE MIND OF MAN
Walls around statue
ALLMIGHTY GOD HATH CREATED THE MIND FREE. ALL ATTEMPTS TO INFLUENCE IT BY TEMPORAL PUNISHMENTS OR BURTHENS...ARE A DEPARTURE FROM THE PLAN OF THE HOLY AUTHOR OF OUR RELIGION..NO MAN SHALL BE COMPELLED TO FREQUENT OR SUPPORT ANY RELIOGIOUS WORSHIP OR MINISTRY OR SHALL OTHERWISE SUFFER ON ACCOUNT OF HIS RELIGIOUS OPINIONS OR BELIEF, BUT ALL MEN SHALL BE FREE TO PROFESS AND BY ARGUMENT TO MAINTAIN, THEIR OPINIONS IN MATTER OF RELIGION. I KNOW BUT ONE CODE OF MORALITY FOR MEN WHETHER ACTING SINGLY OR COLLECTIVELY.
GOD WHO GAVE US LIFE GAVE US LIBERTY. CAN THE LIBERTIES OF A NATION BE SECURE WHEN WE HAVE REMOVED A CONVICTION THAT THESE LIBERTIES ARE THE GIFT OF GOD? INDEED I TREMBLE FOR MY COUNTRY WHEN I REFLECT THAT GOD IS JUST, THAT HIS JUSTICE CANNOT SLEEP FOREVER. COMMERCE BETWEEN MASTER AND SLAVE IS DESPOTISM. NOTHING IS MORE CERTAINLY WRITTEN IN THE BOOK OF FATE THAN THAT THESE PEOPLE ARE TO BE FREE. ESTABLISH THE LAW FOR EDUCATING THE COMMON PEOPLE. THIS IT IS THE BUSINESS OF THE STATE TO EFFECT AND ON A GENERAL PLAN.
I AM NOT AN ADVOCATE FOR FREQUENT CHANGES IN LAWS AND CONSTITUTIONS. BUT LAWS AND INSTITUTIONS MUST GO HAND IN HAND WITH THE PROGRESS OF THE HUMAN MIND. AS THAT BECOMES MORE DEVELOPED, MORE ENLIGHTENED, AS NEW DISCOVERIES ARE MADE, NEW TRUTHS DISCOVERED AND MANNERS AND OPINIONS CHANGE, WITH THE CHANGE OF CIRCUMSTANCES, INSTITUTIONS MUST ADVANCE ALSO TO KEEP PACE WITH THE TIMES. WE MIGHT AS WELL REQUITE A MAN TO WEAR STILL THE COAT WHICH FITTED HIM WHEN A BOY AS CIVILIZED SOCIETY TO REMAIN EVER UNDER THE REGIMEN OF THEIR BARBAROUS ANCESTORS.
WE HOLD THESE TRUTHS TO BE SELF-EVIDENT: THAT ALL MEN ARE CREATED EQUAL, THAT THEY ARE ENDOWED BY THEIR CREATOR WITH CERTAIN INALIENABLE RIGHTS, AMONG THESE ARE LIFE, LIBERTY AND THE PURSUIT OF HAPPINESS, THAT TO SECURE THESE RIGHTS GOVERNMENTS ARE INSTITUTED AMONG MEN. WE SOLEMNLY PUBLISH AND DECLARE, THAT THESE COLONIES ARE AND OF RIGHT OUGHT TO BE FREE AND INDEPENDENT STATES...AND FOR THE SUPPORT OF THIS DECLARATION, WITH A FIRM RELIANCE ON THE PROTECTION OF DIVINE PROVIDENCE, WE MUTUALLY PLEDGE OUR LIVES, OUR FORTUNES AND OUR SACRED HONOUR.
Dedication
MEMORIAL TO THOMAS JEFFERSON
THIRD PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
ERECTED UNDER THE DIRECTION OF
THE THOMAS JEFFERSON MEMORIAL COMMISSION
CREATED BY AN ACT OF CONGRESS, APPROVED JUNE 26, 1934
CHAIRMEN OF THE COMMISSION
JOHN J. BOYLAN 1935-1938 STUART G. GIBBONEY 1938-1944
MEMBERS OF THE COMMISSION
CHARLES O. ANDREWS AUGUSTINE LONERGAN
T. JEFFERSON COOLIDGE CHARLES L. McNARY
FRANCIS D. CULKIN HOLLINS N. RANDOLPH
JEFFERSON RANDOLPH KEAN GEORGE J. RYAN
FISKE KIMBALL HOWARD W. SMITH
FRITZ G. LANHAM ELBERT D. THOMAS
JOSEPH P. TUMULTY
EXECUTIVE AGENT
DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR
NATIONAL PARK SERVICE
CHIEF OF CONSTRUCTION
FRANCIS F. GILLEN
ARCHITECTS
JOHN RUSSELL POPE
1874-1937
ASSOCIATES
OTTO R. EGGERS DANIEL P. HIGGINS
BUILDER
JOHN McSHAIN
audioDescription:
(368 words)
The Thomas Jefferson Memorial sits along the south edge of the Tidal Basin in West Potomac Park in Washington, DC
East Basin Drive, SW bends around the south side of the memorial. Walkways lead north on either side of a seventy-square foot lawn to a path that arcs around both sides to the memorial front entrance along the Tidal Basin.
The Jefferson Memorial building is a circular, open-air structure featuring a shallow dome supported by a circular colonnade composed of twenty-six columns. An additional twelve columns support the north portico, and four columns stand in each of the memorials four openings to the north, south, east and west. A sculpture set in the triangular roof line of the memorial's north side depicts five men, two seated on either side of a man standing at a large document laid across a table.
The memorial is constructed of white marble and rests upon a series of granite and marble-stepped terraces. A flight of granite and marble stairs and platforms, flanked by granite buttresses, lead up from the Tidal Basin.
A nineteen-foot tall bronze statue of Thomas Jefferson in a long fur-collared coat stands atop a six-foot tall black granite pedestal in the center of the dome-roofed main chamber. Jefferson's left foot is set forward slightly and he holds rolled up papers in his left hand. An inscription on the face of the pedestal base reads:
THOMAS JEFFERSON
1743-1826
The interior roof is adorned with a rectangular block design. Four quotations topped with bronze wreaths are carved into the walls of the main chamber and an inscription around the lower edge of the chamber dome interior reads:
I HAVE SWORN UPON THE ALTAR OF GOD ETERNAL HOSTILITY AGAINST EVERY FORM OF TYRANNY OVER THE MIND OF MAN
A bookstore sits on the east side of the main entrance into the memorial at the top of the stairs. An inscription on the wall above the entrance dedicates the memorial.
A curved plaza runs about forty feet from the bottom of the memorial steps to the edge of the Tidal Basin. Views north show the Washington Monument rising from beyond cherry blossom trees ringing the calm waters of the Tidal Basin.
END OF DESCRIPTION
passportStampLocationDescription: 16 East Basin Drive SW, Washington DC 20242 Passport stamps are located in the lower level bookstore. Access the lower level from the doors on either side of the main stairs, or by taking the elevator from the chamber level. Find the following park stamps at this location: George Mason Memorial National Mall and Memorial Parks Thomas Jefferson Memorial Titanic Memorial West Potomac Park

passportStampImages.altText: Circle with arced text Park Name Here Date Year, Washington, DC.
passportStampImages.title: Find stamps for several locations here.

title: Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission and Planners

images.altText: Stone wall with names carved into it
images.title: Thomas Jefferson Commission Members
images.caption: Thomas Jefferson Commission Members

bodyText: This engraving identifies the members of the all-white male Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission and those responsible for the planning, design, and construction of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial. Can you guess which members of the commission were descendants of Thomas Jefferson? The three names most important to the story of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial are John J. Boylan as commission chairman; Fiske Kimball as the noted expert on Thomas Jefferson’s architectural career; and John Russell Pope the architect.

title: Thomas Jefferson Memorial Plaza
bodyText: With its view of the White House, the location south of the Washington Monument along the Tidal Basin was regarded as the last undeveloped site for a significant memorial within the core composition of the National Mall. The final spot of honor was of interest to many. A proposed Theodore Roosevelt Memorial project had failed in 1925 leaving this location available ten years later. In 1935 the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission was determined to secure the site to fulfill the proposed design laid out by the 1901 McMillan Plan.

title: Thomas Jefferson Memorial Rotunda

images.altText: Rounded stone ceiling with letters carved around the interior rim
images.title: Thomas Jefferson Memorial Rotunda
images.caption: Thomas Jefferson Memorial Rotunda

bodyText:
"...I have sworn upon the altar of god eternal hostility against every form of tyranny over the mind of man." - Jefferson to Dr. Benjamin Rush, September 23, 1800 

All the chamber inscriptions are taken from the writings of Thomas Jefferson. This inscription consists of three-foot tall letters carved into the interior marble wall at the bottom of the rotunda. These words underscore Thomas Jefferson as an American contributor to the Enlightenment movement of the 18th Century, and his belief in the primacy of the power of the human mind.

title: Thomas Jefferson Memorial: Statue of Jefferson
listingDescription: This bronze designed by Rudulph Evans depicts Thomas Jefferson holding a rolled piece of paper, suggesting his stature as a man of words. Head to the rear of the statue to find hidden features including crops and books that serve as the foundation of Jefferson's worldview.

images.altText: Larger-than-life statue in round memorial with inscriptions and columns.
images.title: Thomas Jefferson Statue
images.caption: Thomas Jefferson Statue

bodyText: This bronze designed by Rudulph Evans depicts Thomas Jefferson holding a rolled piece of paper, suggesting his stature as a man of words. Head to the rear of the statue to find hidden features including crops and books that serve as the foundation of Jefferson's worldview.
audioDescription:
(310 words)
The Thomas Jefferson Memorial sits along the south edge of the Tidal Basin in West Potomac Park in Washington, DC
The memorial building is a circular, open-air structure featuring a shallow dome supported by a circular colonnade composed of twenty-six columns. An additional twelve columns support the north portico, and four columns stand in each of the memorials four openings to the north, south, east and west. A sculpture set in the triangular roof line of the memorial's north side depicts five men, two seated on either side of a man standing at a large document laid across a table.
The memorial is constructed of white marble and rests upon a series of granite and marble-stepped terraces. A flight of granite and marble stairs and platforms, flanked by granite buttresses, lead up from the Tidal Basin. A silhouette of tall figure can be seen standing inside through the columns of the memorial.
Set in the center of the domed main chamber is a nineteen-foot tall bronze statue of Thomas Jefferson in a long fur-collared coat standing atop a six-foot tall black granite pedestal. Jefferson's left foot is set forward slightly and he holds rolled up papers in his left hand. His right hand holds a quill pen. Set behind the statue's right foot are two column capitals, partially hidden by the back of Jefferson's long coat. An inscription on the face of the pedestal base reads:
THOMAS JEFFERSON
1743-1826
An inscription on the left edge of the statue base reads:
R. EVANS
The interior roof is adorned with a rectangular block design. Four quotations topped with bronze wreaths are carved into the walls of the main chamber and an inscription around the lower edge of the chamber dome interior reads:
I HAVE SWORN UPON THE ALTAR OF GOD ETERNAL HOSTILITY AGAINST EVERY FORM OF TYRANNY OVER THE MIND OF MAN
END OF DESCRIPTION
